articles.headline: Bernie Sanders Endorses Joe Biden for President
articles.snippet: At a moment when Mr. Biden still faces deep skepticism from many younger progressive voters, Mr. Sanders’s support is a major step toward Democratic unity against President Trump.
articles.abstract: At a moment when Mr. Biden still faces deep skepticism from many younger progressive voters, Mr. Sanders’s support is a major step toward Democratic unity against President Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders endorsed Joseph R. Biden Jr. as the Democratic nominee for president on Monday, adding the weight of his left-wing support to Mr. Biden’s candidacy and taking a major step toward bringing unity to the party’s effort to unseat President Trump in November.
articles.byline: By Sydney Ember and Katie Glueck

articles.headline: Economic Pain Will Persist Long After Lockdowns End
articles.snippet: President Trump has predicted an economic boom once stay-at-home and other restrictions are lifted. But economic activity is likely to remain subdued until the threat of the coronavirus recedes.
articles.abstract: President Trump has predicted an economic boom once stay-at-home and other restrictions are lifted. But economic activity is likely to remain subdued until the threat of the coronavirus recedes.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Walter Isenberg is the sort of business owner President Trump has in mind when he talks about the need to start lifting coronavirus lockdowns and reopen the American economy. Mr. Isenberg’s hotel and restaurant group in Denver has seen its revenues drop from $3 million a day last year to $40,000 a day now.

articles.headline: The Big Deal to Cut Oil Production May Not Be Big Enough
articles.snippet: Saudi Arabia, Russia and other oil-producing nations have pledged to cut about 10 percent of global production, but demand is down by much more than that.
articles.abstract: Saudi Arabia, Russia and other oil-producing nations have pledged to cut about 10 percent of global production, but demand is down by much more than that.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The agreement by major oil producers on Sunday to reduce their daily production by 9.7 million barrels was the largest cutback in history and a feat of remarkable coordination by more than 20 nations led by Saudi Arabia and Russia with unusual mediation from the United States.

articles.headline: U.S. Food Supply Chain Is Strained as Virus Spreads
articles.snippet: Disruptions are expected in the production and distribution of products like pork, and localized shortages could occur.
articles.abstract: Disruptions are expected in the production and distribution of products like pork, and localized shortages could occur.
articles.lead_paragraph: The nation’s food supply chain is showing signs of strain, as increasing numbers of workers are falling ill with the coronavirus in meat processing plants, warehouses and grocery stores.
articles.byline: By Michael Corkery and David Yaffe-Bellany

articles.headline: How Bad Will the Economy Get? Companies Will Provide Clues
articles.snippet: The quarterly parade of corporate earnings and management comments could reveal how much damage the pandemic will do and how long the pain will last.
articles.abstract: The quarterly parade of corporate earnings and management comments could reveal how much damage the pandemic will do and how long the pain will last.
articles.lead_paragraph: The coronavirus pandemic has pushed the economy into a slowdown of unknown severity. It could be a long, drawn-out recession, or a sharp dip followed by a swift recovery.
articles.byline: By Peter Eavis and Matt Phillips

articles.headline: ‘Accelerate the Endgame’: Obama’s Role in Wrapping Up the Primary
articles.snippet: The former president has kept his political distance from Joe Biden. But he’s been much more engaged in the race’s denouement than has been previously revealed.
articles.abstract: The former president has kept his political distance from Joe Biden. But he’s been much more engaged in the race’s denouement than has been previously revealed.
articles.lead_paragraph: Over the past year, Joseph R. Biden Jr. and former President Barack Obama practiced a political distancing of sorts, with Mr. Obama maintaining a posture of public neutrality in the Democratic primaries, offering counsel to any candidate who called (most did), and Mr. Biden saying he wanted to win on his own.

articles.headline: ‘Overwhelmed and Frustrated’: What It’s Like Trying to Get an Abortion in Texas
articles.snippet: Pregnant women are scrambling to get access to the procedure, driving hundreds of miles out of state. The fight has resulted in a flurry of court rulings.
articles.abstract: Pregnant women are scrambling to get access to the procedure, driving hundreds of miles out of state. The fight has resulted in a flurry of court rulings.
articles.lead_paragraph: The 31-year-old from Houston knew she did not want another baby. She already had three — her youngest, a boy, was just 6 months old. And she had just been laid off from her job in a medical billing office, another casualty of America’s growing unemployment crisis.

articles.headline: ‘This Is Going to Kill Small-Town America’
articles.snippet: Once the coronavirus reached rural Bristol, N.H., the effect on the local economy was devastating.
articles.abstract: Once the coronavirus reached rural Bristol, N.H., the effect on the local economy was devastating.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRISTOL, N.H. — The coronavirus itself was slow to arrive in Bristol, a lakeside town of 3,300 people. The economic destruction came swiftly.

articles.headline: Japan Needs to Telework. Its Paper-Pushing Offices Make That Hard.
articles.snippet: The government says working remotely is crucial to halting the coronavirus, but a workplace culture of official seals, fax machines and face-to-face meetings hinders that effort.
articles.abstract: The government says working remotely is crucial to halting the coronavirus, but a workplace culture of official seals, fax machines and face-to-face meetings hinders that effort.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Officially, Shuhei Aoyama has been teleworking for a month. But that doesn’t mean he can avoid going to the office.
articles.byline: By Ben Dooley and Makiko Inoue
